questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient undergoes routine examination and found to have Hb of 9.2 g/dL and 2+ protein in urine. General examination revealed hypertension. Renal biopsy was performed for proteinuria. Vascular changes are present in the biopsy, image of which is shown below. The Congo red stain is negative. What are the vascular changes seen in the biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The biopsy image shows a small renal arteriole with a homogenous, pink, glassy appearance of the vessel wall, which is characteristic of Hyaline Arteriosclerosis.
  • The lumen appears narrowed, and the vessel wall is thickened due to the accumulation of eosinophilic hyaline material. This finding is consistent with chronic vascular injury typically seen in long-standing hypertension.
  • Hyaline arteriosclerosis is a pathological process involving the leakage of plasma proteins into the vessel wall and increased synthesis of extracellular matrix by smooth muscle cells. It commonly affects small arteries and arterioles, especially in the kidneys, and is frequently associated with benign hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The changes result in progressive narrowing of the vessel lumen, leading to ischemic injury and contributing to chronic kidney disease.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Malignant arteriosclerosis (Option B): This is associated with malignant hypertension (very high blood pressure with acute end-organ damage) and shows fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls and onion-skinning (hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis) on histology. It is a more acute and severe process than hyaline arteriosclerosis and is not consistent with the image or the patient's relatively stable clinical picture.

Atherosclerosis (Option C): Affects large and medium-sized arteries, not small renal arterioles. It involves the formation of intimal plaques composed of lipid, cholesterol, inflammatory cells, and fibrous tissue. It is not seen in glomerular or interlobular arterioles on renal biopsy, and the absence of lipid-laden plaques or calcification in the image rules this out.

Fibrosed vessel (Option D): This is a nonspecific term indicating chronic scarring or sclerosis of a vessel. While fibrosis may be present in various vascular pathologies, the term does not specifically describe the hyaline material depositionseen in this image.

choices.text: Acute inflammation of the vessel wall
Granulomatous Inflammation in the vessel wall
Lipid deposition and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man having a familial history of diabetes was diagnosed with diabetes 6 years back. She has uncontrolled sugar level along with systemic hypertension. He suddenly dies of congestive heart failure. The luminal surface of the abdominal aorta is shown in the image. Which of the following pathologic changes would you expect to see on microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The gross image of the abdominal aorta in this elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient who died of congestive heart failure shows irregular, yellow-white, raised lesions on the intimal surface, consistent with atherosclerotic plaques.

  • These plaques typically affect large and medium-sized arteries, such as the aorta, and are frequently seen in individuals with risk factors like diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and advanced age.
  • On microscopic examination, the expected pathological finding is lipid deposition and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia, along with the presence of foam cells, cholesterol clefts, necrotic debris, and fibrous cap formation-hallmarks of atherosclerosis.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Acute inflammation of the vessel wall (Option A): This is seen in vasculitis, particularly in infectious or immune-mediated conditions (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa). It does not account for the atherosclerotic plaques seen in the image or the clinical scenario of chronic metabolic disease.

Granulomatous inflammation in the vessel wall (Option B): Seen in specific types of vasculitis like giant cell arteritisor Takayasu arteritis. It is not a feature of atherosclerosis and would present differently, often with constitutional symptoms and involvement of branches of the aortic arch.

Cystic medial necrosis (Option C): Characterized by degeneration of elastic tissue and accumulation of basophilic ground substance in the aortic media. It is typically associated with aortic dissection, especially in patients with Marfan syndrome, not atherosclerosis.

questions.text: 68-year-old male patient on routine laboratory investigations found to have high cholesterol level. Relevant history shows he has abnormal lipid profile since many years which must have lead to generation of atherosclerosis in blood vessels. Fatty streaks lead to increased attachment of monocytes to endothelium and migration to subendothelium, transform themselves into foam cells. Which of the following substances is most likely to be responsible for the transformation of macrophages?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atherosclerosis begins with endothelial injury, often due to chronic hyperlipidemia.

  • This leads to increased permeability and adhesion of monocytes to the vascular endothelium.
  • These monocytes migrate into the intima and differentiate into macrophages.
  • The transformation of macrophages into foam cells-a key feature of early atherosclerotic plaques such as fatty streaks-is primarily driven by the uptake of oxidized LDL (low-density lipoprotein).
  • Oxidized LDL is formed when LDL particles become modified by oxidative stress in the vascular wall.
  • Macrophages take up this oxidized LDL via scavenger receptors (not the normal LDL receptor), leading to the formation of lipid-laden foam cells.
  • These foam cells accumulate in the intima, releasing pro-inflammatory cytokines and growth factors that contribute to plaque progression.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

C-reactive protein (Option A): An acute-phase reactant and marker of systemic inflammation. While elevated CRP is associated with increased cardiovascular risk, it does not cause foam cell formation.

Reduced LDL (Option B): A lower level of LDL is actually protective against atherosclerosis. It is the oxidized form of LDL, not reduced LDL, that contributes to foam cell formation.

Lp(a) (Option C): Lipoprotein(a) is an LDL-like particle associated with increased risk of atherosclerosis and thrombosis, but it does not directly mediate macrophage transformation into foam cells.

choices.text: Abnormal transforming growth factor beta signaling
Inflammation leading to collagen degradation and alteration
Weakening of vascular wall due to loss of smooth muscle cell or generation of noncollagen extracellular matrix

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain. History taking revealed he has hypertension since long duration and also smokes since very long time. Radiological investigations were performed which show pulsating mid line mass, possibly an aneurysm. Which of the following statements are true regarding its pathogenesis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with features suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)- a pulsatile midline abdominal mass in the setting of long-standing hypertension and chronic smoking, both of which are major risk factors.

  • The pathogenesis of AAA is multifactorial, involving complex molecular and structural changes in the aortic wall.
  • TGF-β plays a critical role in maintaining vascular wall integrity by regulating extracellular matrix (ECM) production and repair.
  • Abnormal TGF-β signaling can impair this balance, contributing to weakening of the vessel wall. (Option A)
  • Chronic inflammation, especially from smoking, activates macrophages and other immune cells.
  • These cells release matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) that degrade collagen and elastin, weakening the aortic wall and facilitating aneurysm formation. (Option B)
  • Loss of smooth muscle cells from oxidative stress, aging, or inflammation compromises the structural integrity of the vessel.
  • Additionally, the ECM may be replaced by disorganized, non-collagenous matrix, reducing tensile strength and promoting aneurysmal dilation. (Option C)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient diagnosed as having hyperlipidemia on screening tests or a routine physical and laboratory investigations. Laboratory studies show total serum cholesterol of 350 mg/dL, LDL of 280 mg/dL, HDL of 37 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 380 mg/dL. This patient is symptomatic, however, is most at risk of developing an aneurysm in which of the following anatomic locations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 65-year-old patient has marked hyperlipidemia with extremely elevated total cholesterol, LDL, and triglycerides, along with a low HDL.

  • These lipid abnormalities, especially when combined with advanced age, strongly predispose to atherosclerosis.
  • The abdominal aorta is the most common site for atherosclerotic aneurysm formation, particularly below the renal arteries.
  • The abdominal aorta is subject to high hemodynamic stress and has relatively fewer vasa vasorum, making it more vulnerable to ischemic injury of the vessel wall.
  • Atherosclerosis preferentially affects large elastic arteries, and the infrarenal abdominal aorta is the most frequently involved site in aneurysm formation due to atherosclerosis.
  • Risk factors such as hyperlipidemia, hypertension, smoking, and male sex all contribute to degeneration of the aortic wall, leading to aneurysm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with vague symptoms of mild fever, fatigue but with an intense unilateral throbbing headache on the left lateral side of scalp. While eating, pain is on the mandible, and blood vessels are palpable when pain is intense. A small vascular biopsy was performed and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 55-year-old male presents with a classic clinical picture of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis.

  • The key features include:
    • Unilateral throbbing headache, especially over the temporal region
    • Jaw claudication (pain in the mandible while chewing)
    • Tender, thickened temporal artery that may be palpable
    • Constitutional symptoms like low-grade fever and fatigue
  • The histopathological image typically shows:
    • Granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall
    • Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina
    • Multinucleated giant cells infiltrating the intima and media
    • Lymphocytic infiltration and intimal thickening leading to luminal narrowing

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Takayasu arteritis (Option A):

  • A large vessel vasculitis like GCA but usually occurs in younger women (<40 years).
  • Involves the aortic arch and its branches, leading to absent pulses or blood pressure discrepancies.
  • Headache and jaw claudication are not typical presenting symptoms.

Leucocytoclastic vasculitis (Option C):

  • A small vessel vasculitis primarily affecting postcapillary venules.
  • Presents with palpable purpura on skin, especially lower limbs.
  • Histology shows neutrophilic infiltration and nuclear debris (leukocytoclasia), not granulomatous inflammation or giant cells.

Wegener's granulomatosis (Option D): (now known as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

  • A small-to-medium vessel vasculitis associated with necrotizing granulomas, often affecting the respiratory tract and kidneys.
  • c-ANCA positive.
  • Not typically associated with temporal artery involvement or jaw claudication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the emergency with chest pain, proper history taking revealed infrequent symptoms of bloody stools, abdominal pain, and sometimes uncontrolled hypertension. He is positive for HBsAg. MI is properly managed, and biopsy of the vessels shows thrombosis with fibrinoid necrosis as shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of this 45-year-old male-with chest pain, episodes of bloody stools, abdominal pain, uncontrolled hypertension, and a positive HBsAg status-points strongly toward polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

  • The biopsy findings showing thrombosis and fibrinoid necrosis of medium-sized arteries further support this diagnosis.
  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects medium-sized muscular arteries, sparing smaller vessels such as capillaries and arterioles.
  • It is classically associated with Hepatitis B virus, and can involve multiple organs, leading to complications such as mesenteric ischemia, renal infarctions, and myocardial infarction, all of which can arise from vascular thrombosis and ischemia.
  • Histologically, PAN is characterized by segmental transmural inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and thrombosis, often in vessels at varying stages of involvement.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Atherosclerosis (Option A): Involves lipid-laden plaques and chronic inflammation in large and medium arteries, but does not show fibrinoid necrosis or the acute vessel wall damage seen in vasculitis.

Aortic dissection (Option C): Typically results from intimal tearing and affects the aorta, not medium muscular arteries. It does not show fibrinoid necrosis and is unrelated to hepatitis B or systemic vasculitis features.

Kawasaki disease (Option D): A medium vessel vasculitis but occurs in children, presenting with mucocutaneous inflammation and coronary aneurysms. It is not associated with hepatitis B and is unlikely in a 45-year-old adult.

choices.text: It results from delayed type hypersensitivity response
Histopathological examination will reveal dense transmural inflammatory infiltrate
Pathological changes are systemic and significantly affect kidney and liver
Immunoglobulin and aspirin therapy improve the symptoms

questions.text: A 2-year-old male baby presented with redness of the eye, erythema of the hand and feet along with cervical lymph node enlargement. He also complains of the presence of fever. Based on the above clinical findings, all of the following statements are true regarding the disease except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of this 2-year-old male - with fever, bilateral conjunctival injection (red eyes), erythema of hands and feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy - is highly characteristic of Kawasaki disease, a medium-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects children under 5 years of age.

  • While Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis, the major organ at risk is the cardiovascular system, particularly the coronary arteries.
  • Renal and hepatic involvement is minimal or nonspecific, and not a primary concern in its pathophysiology.
  • Key Features of Kawasaki Disease:
    • Fever lasting ≥5 days
    • Bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis
    • Mucocutaneous changes: cracked lips, strawberry tongue
    • Extremity changes: erythema, edema, later desquamation
    • Polymorphous rash
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of recent occurrence of respiratory distress after some strenuous exercise. Physical examination reveals mild hypertension (blood pressure = 150/100 mm Hg), bilateral wheezing, and numerous purpuric skin lesions on the feet. Laboratory investigations performed show presence of raised TLC (15300/μL) and eosinophilia, serum creatinine is elevated to 3.5 mg/dL. The serum ANCA test is positive. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria and RBCs. A renal biopsy demonstrates vasculitis accompanied by eosinophilia. Based on the above findings what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 28-year-old man presents with respiratory symptoms (wheezing, dyspnea), purpuric skin lesions, eosinophilia, elevated creatinine, proteinuria with hematuria, and positive ANCA - all of which point toward a small-vessel vasculitis involving multiple organ systems.

  • The renal biopsy showing vasculitis with eosinophilic infiltration is particularly diagnostic.
  • These findings are classic for Churg-Strauss disease, now called Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA).
  • It is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis characterized by:
    • Asthma or allergic symptoms (often precede systemic findings)
    • Peripheral eosinophilia
    • Extravascular granulomas
    • Palpable purpura (from skin vasculitis)
    • Renal involvement (as shown by proteinuria and elevated creatinine)
    • Positive p-ANCA (often anti-MPO antibodies)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (Option B):

  • Also causes palpable purpura, especially in children.
  • Typically involves IgA deposition, presents with abdominal pain, arthralgia, and renal involvement, but eosinophilia and asthma are not features.

Wegener's granulomatosis (Option C):

  • Now called Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA).
  • Involves upper and lower respiratory tract + kidneys, but usually shows necrotizing granulomas, c-ANCA positivity, and lacks marked eosinophilia.

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option D):

  • Affects medium-sized arteries, typically spares the lungs, and is not ANCA-associated.
  • Often linked with HBV, and does not feature eosinophilia or asthma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with symptoms of sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcer and chronic cough. Laboratory findings revealed deranged kidney function test and PR3-ANCA positivity. Urine analysis shows presence of proteinuria and RBCs. Chest X-ray shows bilateral nodular lesions in lung. A transbronchial lung biopsy specimen shows a necrotizing inflammatory process involving the small peripheral pulmonary arteries and arterioles. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of this 48-year-old male - with sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcer, chronic cough, proteinuria, hematuria, and deranged renal function - along with imaging showing bilateral pulmonary nodular lesions and PR3-ANCA positivity, is characteristic of Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis.

  • GPA is a necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, and it classically involves the upper and lower respiratory tracts as well as the kidneys.
  • The lung biopsy showing necrotizing inflammation of peripheral pulmonary arteries and arterioles, along with granulomatous features, further supports this diagnosis.
  • GPA commonly presents with c-ANCA (PR3-ANCA) positivity and can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Polyarteritis nodosa (Option A) typically involves medium-sized arteries, spares the lungs, and is not associated with ANCA or granulomatous inflammation.

Kaposi sarcoma (Option C) is a vascular tumor seen in immunocompromised patients, not associated with vasculitis or ANCA.

Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D) is another ANCA-associated small vessel vasculitis but lacks granulomatous inflammation and rarely affects the upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented with gradually increasing neck swelling. On radiological investigation performed, it shows high vascularity. Excision was done and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a 2-year-old child with a gradually enlarging, highly vascular neck mass is strongly suggestive of a benign vascular tumor, most likely a capillary hemangioma. These are the most common benign vascular tumors in infancy and early childhood.

  • Histologically, capillary hemangiomas are characterized by:
    • Numerous small, capillary-sized blood vessels that are tightly packed
    • Each vessel is lined by a single layer of bland endothelial cells
    • The surrounding stroma may be fibrous or show areas of inflammation
    • The lesion is well-circumscribed and lacks cellular atypia or necrosis
  • These tumors often appear within the first few weeks of life, grow rapidly, and then involute spontaneously over time.
  • They are commonly seen on the skin, head, neck, or mucosal surfaces.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Cavernous hemangioma (Option B):

  • Composed of large, dilated vascular spaces rather than capillary-sized vessels
  • Lesions are more deep-seated, and histology shows irregular, blood-filled channels with thin walls
  • Less common in young children compared to capillary hemangiomas

Kaposi sarcoma (Option C):

  • A vascular neoplasm associated with HHV-8, seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS)
  • Histology shows spindle cells, slit-like vascular spaces, and extravasated RBCs
  • Very rare in healthy young children

Angiosarcoma (Option D):

  • A malignant vascular tumor with infiltrative growth, cytologic atypia, and high mitotic activity
  • Occurs in older adults, often in the skin, liver, or breast
  • Histologically aggressive and not compatible with this clinical scenario

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a gingival swelling which is in color. Surgeon saw it's a polyp like structure and excision of the lesion is done and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 25-year-old male presents with a gingival swelling that appears polyp-like, and histopathological examination reveals features consistent with a cavernous hemangioma.

  • Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular lesionscomposed of large, dilated blood-filled vascular spaces.
  • These lesions are often found in deeper tissues, including the oral cavity, and can present as soft, red or purple nodules that may bleed easily upon manipulation.
  • Histologically, cavernous hemangiomas show:
    • Large, dilated vascular spaces lined by a single layer of flattened endothelial cells
    • The vascular channels are often filled with blood
    • Unlike capillary hemangiomas, the vessels are irregular and cavernous (wide-lumen)
    • There is minimal cytologic atypia and no evidence of malignancy

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Capillary hemangioma (Option A):

  • Composed of numerous small, tightly packed capillary-sized vessels
  • More common in infants and children, and typically found on skin or superficial mucosa
  • Not characterized by large vascular channels as seen in this case

Kaposi sarcoma (Option C):

  • A low-grade malignant vascular tumor associated with HHV-8, usually seen in immunocompromised patients(e.g., HIV)
  • Histology shows spindle-shaped cells, slit-like vascular spaces, and extravasated RBCs
  • Not consistent with a well-circumscribed polyp-like lesion in a healthy young adult

Angiosarcoma (Option D):

  • A high-grade malignant vascular tumor
  • Histology shows marked cellular atypia, mitoses, infiltrative borders, and poorly formed vascular channels
  • Rare in the gingiva and not consistent with a benign-appearing lesion

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented in the emergency room with 3 hours of chest pain. Trop T performed by rapid diagnostic assay shows positive result. Other laboratory studies performed shows increased leukocyte count and increased serum levels of other cardiac enzymes. ECG confirms a massive transmural myocardial infarction of the left ventricle. The patient dies duration later. Histopathological Examination (image shown below) of injured heart muscle had shown some characteristics features to decide the timing of death.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At approximately 48 hours (2 days) after a myocardial infarction, the heart tissue shows distinct histological features that help in estimating the time of injury:

  • Histopathological features at 2 days post-MI:
    • Extensive coagulative necrosis of myocardial fibers
    • Loss of nuclei and striations
    • Infiltration by neutrophils becomes prominent (acute inflammatory response)
    • Edema and hemorrhage may also be present
    • Muscle fibers appear hypereosinophilic with interstitial neutrophilic infiltrates

These findings are distinct from earlier stages and help pin the timeline to approximately 48 hours.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented in the emergency room with sudden onset of chest pain. The ECG done shows normal wave pattern. Analysis of which pair of serum markers given below would be most helpful in excluding a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a 46-year-old male presenting with sudden onset chest pain and a normal ECG, the most appropriate serum markers to help exclude a diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) are CK-MB and cardiac troponin-I.

  • These two biomarkers are both specific to cardiac muscle injury and are widely used in clinical practice for diagnosing or ruling out MI.
  • Troponin-I is highly sensitive and specific, beginning to rise within 3-6 hours of myocardial injury and remaining elevated for up to 7-10 days.
  • CK-MB, although slightly less specific than troponin, also rises within 3-6 hours, peaks at 12-24 hours, and returns to baseline within 2-3 days, making it particularly useful for detecting reinfarction.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Cardiac troponin-I and myoglobin (Option A): Troponin-I is a highly sensitive and specific marker for myocardial injury and is appropriate for MI diagnosis.However, myoglobin, though it rises very early, is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated in any muscle injury. While this combination may detect early MI, it lacks the combined specificity and time coverage provided by CK-MB and troponin-I, making it less ideal for confidently excluding an AMI.

CK-BB and myoglobin (Option B):CK-BB is an isoenzyme primarily found in the brain and lungs, not in cardiac muscle. It is not used in the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
Myoglobin is an early marker of muscle injury (rises within 1-2 hours), but it is non-specific, as it is found in both cardiac and skeletal muscle. Thus, this pair lacks specificity for cardiac injury and is not suitable for excluding AMI.

CK-MM and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)-1 (Option D):CK-MM is the major isoenzyme found in skeletal muscle, not the heart, and is therefore not useful in detecting myocardial infarction. LDH-1 was historically used to detect MI, especially the "LDH flip" (LDH-1 > LDH-2), but it is nonspecific, rises late (24-48 hours), and has largely been replaced by more reliable and specific markers like troponins. This combination is outdated and lacks clinical utility in the acute setting.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, presented to the hospital with chest pain and respiratory distress. On physical examination, the patient is having shortness of breath, wheezing, and gasping for air. A prominent pansystolic heart murmur heard on cardiac auscultation. An X-ray study of the chest shows marked enlargement of the heart. The patient expires despite intense supportive measures. An autopsy was performed, and an image of microscopic examination of the myocardium is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 12-year-old girl presenting with chest pain, respiratory distress, pansystolic murmur, cardiomegaly on X-ray, and sudden death is highly suggestive of acute carditis, likely due to acute rheumatic fever (ARF)-especially in this age group.

  • The microscopic image shows features like:
    • Aschoff bodies (granulomatous lesions with central fibrinoid necrosis)
    • Anitschkow cells ("caterpillar" cells - activated histiocytes with centrally wavy chromatin)
  • These are pathognomonic histological findings of acute rheumatic carditis, confirming the diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever.
  • Acute Rheumatic Fever is an autoimmune, nonsuppurative sequela that occurs after a Group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GAS) pharyngeal infection, typically 2-3 weeks
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Molecular mimicry: Antibodies generated against streptococcal M proteins cross-react with cardiac tissue, joints, skin, and CNS.
    • Type II hypersensitivity reaction is central to its pathophysiology.
  • Clinical Features (Based on Modified Jones Criteria):
  • Major Criteria:
    • Carditis (can involve endocardium, myocardium, or pericardium)
      • Tachycardia, new murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation), cardiomegaly, pericardial rub, heart failure.
      • Histology: Aschoff bodies, Anitschkow cells.
    • Polyarthritis
      • Migratory, large joint involvement (knees, ankles, elbows, wrists).
    • Sydenham's chorea
      • Involuntary, purposeless, rapid movements; emotional lability; delayed manifestation.
    • Erythema marginatum
      • Non-pruritic, pink rings with clear centers, typically on trunk/proximal limbs.
    • Subcutaneous nodules
      • Firm, painless nodules over extensor surfaces, often near bony prominences.
  • Minor Criteria:
    • Fever
    • Arthralgia (if arthritis is not counted as major)
    • Elevated ESR/CRP
    • Prolonged PR interval on ECG

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Acute bacterial endocarditis (Option A): This typically occurs in individuals with a preexisting valvular abnormality or intravenous drug use. The clinical course is fulminant, but it is more common in adults. Histology would show bacterial colonies with destruction of valve tissue, not Aschoff bodies or Anitschkow cells. It is not the typical cause of sudden death with myocarditis and cardiomegaly in a 12-year-old.

Subacute bacterial endocarditis (Option C): Usually caused by less virulent organisms (e.g., viridans streptococci) and has a more indolent course. It often presents with constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, and anemia over weeks. There is no association with myocarditis or sudden death in previously healthy children. Microscopy would show vegetations with granulation tissue and fibrosis, not Aschoff bodies.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option D): Though SLE can cause Libman-Sacks endocarditis and pericarditis, it usually affects young women, not commonly children this young. Also, it has multi-systemic signs (rash, arthritis, renal involvement), which are not mentioned. Histology would not show Aschoff bodies, but rather fibrinoid necrosis and immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presented with subcutaneous nodules over the skin of her arms and torso 3 weeks after a bout of acute pharyngitis. She manifests some abnormal movements and begins to complain of pain in her knees and hips, particularly with movement. A friction rub is heard on auscultation of her chest. An abnormality detected by which of the following serum laboratory findings is most characteristic of the disease affecting this girl?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 9-year-old girl presenting with subcutaneous nodules, migratory joint pain, abnormal movements, and a friction rub following a recent episode of acute pharyngitis is exhibiting classic features of acute rheumatic fever (ARF).

  • ARF is a post-infectious, autoimmune complication that typically follows group A streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis after a latency of about 2-3 weeks.
  • Her symptoms - including subcutaneous nodules, migratory arthritis (involving knees and hips), Sydenham chorea (abnormal movements), and pericardial involvement (evident as a friction rub) - align with the Jones criteria used to diagnose ARF.
  • Among the laboratory investigations, the most characteristic finding that supports the diagnosis is an elevated Antistreptolysin O (ASO) antibody titer, which reflects a recent streptococcal infection.
  • While anti-DNase B titers may also rise in post-streptococcal illnesses, ASO is more commonly used and specifically indicative of ARF.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Antinuclear antibody titer (Option B): This test is typically positive in autoimmune connective tissue diseases, especially systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although SLE can present with arthritis and serositis (including pericarditis), the presence of chorea, subcutaneous nodules, and a recent streptococcal infection history makes SLE less likely in this context. ANA is not useful in diagnosing ARF.

Anti-DNAase B titer (Option C): While elevated anti-DNAase B levels also indicate a recent streptococcal infection, especially when ASO titers are normal, ASO titers remain the most commonly used and characteristic marker in ARF diagnosis. Anti-DNAase B is more sensitive in certain post-streptococcal conditions like post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rather than ARF specifically.

Troponin I level (Option D): Troponin I is a cardiac biomarker released during myocardial injury, such as in acute myocardial infarction. Although ARF can involve the heart (rheumatic carditis), it typically affects the endocardium and pericardium rather than causing significant myocardial necrosis that would elevate troponins. Therefore, troponin I is not a characteristic laboratory finding in ARF.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents to the emergency with a 24-hour history of fever, shaking chills and disoriented state. Urine analysis for drug abuse shows positive results. He later explained that he started taking ganja and opioids, now started taking drug via IV route. Proper examination shows temperature is 38.7°C (103°F), pulse rate 110 per minute, and blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur. The patient rapidly develops a headache and right-arm paralysis. A CT scan of the brain demonstrates an infarct of the right frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely cause of stroke in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis in this case is Bacetrial Endocarditis.

  • In IV drug users, bacterial endocarditis, particularly right-sided (tricuspid valve) due to Staphylococcus aureus, is a common and serious complication.
  • However, vegetations can also affect the left side and embolize to systemic circulation.
  • In this case, the infarct in the right frontal lobe suggests left-sided endocarditis, likely affecting the mitral or aortic valve, with septic emboli traveling to the brain and causing ischemic stroke.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Atrial myxoma (Option A): Atrial myxomas, particularly in the left atrium, can cause embolic strokes by releasing tumor fragments or thrombi. However, this is much rarer and typically occurs without fever or a new murmur from acute infective pathology. Also, the context of IV drug use points more strongly toward endocarditis.

Dissecting aortic aneurysm (Option C): Aortic dissection may cause stroke if it involves carotid arteries, but this patient has no chest or tearing back pain, and no blood pressure discrepancy or widened mediastinum. It's also not associated with fever, murmur, or IV drug use.

Atrial fibrillation (Option D): AF can lead to embolic strokes due to left atrial thrombus formation. However, there's no mention of irregularly irregular pulse or known AF, and AF would not explain the fever, murmur, or IV drug use history

choices.text: Characteristic deposition of sterile Thrombi on the leaflet of cardiac valves
Histologically these are bland thrombi, loosely attached to the underlying valve
Vegetation are destructive and shows marked inflammatory response
These vegetation have trivial effect but can be a source of emboli

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who had long duration smoking history and diagnosed as a case of small cell carcinoma of lung and on chemotherapy regimen develops a recently developed heart murmur. Undergoes some laboratory tests which revealed normal TLC and negative blood culture. No growth seen on urine culture examination. Possibly noninfective endocarditis was the reason for the heart murmur. All of the following statements are true regarding nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE).

  • NBTE, also known as marantic endocarditis, is a form of noninfective endocarditis characterized by the deposition of sterile thrombi composed mainly of fibrin and platelets on cardiac valve leaflets.
  • It commonly occurs in association with malignancies (especially mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas and small cell carcinoma of the lung), as well as in hypercoagulable states, systemic lupus erythematosus (Libman-Sacks endocarditis), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • In this case, the patient, a chronic smoker diagnosed with small cell carcinoma and currently undergoing chemotherapy, develops a new heart murmur.
  • Blood and urine cultures are negative, and leukocyte counts are normal, making infective endocarditis unlikely and supporting the diagnosis of NBTE.
  • Histologically, NBTE is characterized by bland, sterile vegetations that are loosely attached to the valve surface and composed of fibrin and platelets without significant inflammatory infiltrate or destruction of underlying tissue.
  • These vegetations tend to form along the lines of valve closure, most commonly affecting the mitral and aortic valves.
  • While these vegetations generally have trivial hemodynamic consequences, they are prone to embolization, which can lead to infarctions in organs such as the brain, kidneys, or spleen.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Characteristic deposition of sterile thrombi on the leaflet of cardiac valves (Option A): This is a hallmark feature of NBTE. The vegetations are composed of sterile fibrin and platelet thrombi, typically deposited along the line of valve closure. These vegetations are not caused by microorganisms, distinguishing them from those seen in infective endocarditis.

Histologically these are bland thrombi, loosely attached to the underlying valve (Option B): NBTE vegetations are bland, meaning they lack inflammatory cells or organisms, and are loosely attached to the valve surface. This loose attachment makes them more likely to embolize, and histologically, they show no destruction of the underlying valve tissue.

These vegetation have trivial effect but can be a source of emboli (Option D): NBTE vegetations usually do not cause significant valve dysfunction or hemodynamic compromise, hence the effect on the heart is often trivial. However, they pose a serious risk for systemic embolization, which may lead to infarcts in organs like the brain, kidneys, or spleen, and can be the first clinical presentation in many cases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college athlete suddenly collapses in the middle of game in playground. A cardiac monitor shows ventricular tachycardia. He is successfully resuscitated and hospitalized. The patient's history indicates that his father died suddenly at 38 years of age. The boy's echocardiogram reveals a thickened left ventricular wall, with a small slit- like chamber. The interventricular septum is also markedly thickened. Five years later the patient expires suddenly. Histologic examination of the heart muscle at autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 20-year-old athlete presents with sudden collapse during physical exertion, and is found to have ventricular tachycardia.

  • He has a positive family history of sudden cardiac death (father died at age 38), and echocardiography shows a thickened left ventricular (LV) wall, a small, slit-like LV cavity, and marked interventricular septal hypertrophy.
  • These are all classic findings of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • HCM is a genetic disorder, most often inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, caused by mutations in sarcomeric proteins (such as β-myosin heavy chain, troponin T, or myosin-binding protein C).
  • It is one of the most common causes of sudden cardiac death in young athletes.
  • Death is often due to ventricular arrhythmias triggered by exertion.
  • Histology at autopsy typically reveals:
    • Marked myocyte hypertrophy
    • Disarray of cardiac muscle fibers (myofiber disarray)
    • Interstitial fibrosis

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Amyloidosis (Option A): Amyloidosis causes a restrictive cardiomyopathy, typically in older adults. It leads to stiff ventricles with preserved systolic function. Histology shows extracellular amyloid deposits that stain with Congo red, displaying apple-green birefringence under polarized light. It does not present with asymmetric septal hypertrophy or sudden death in young athletes. Myofiber disarray is not a feature.

Cardiac Myxoma (Option B): Cardiac myxomas are benign tumors, usually arising in the left atrium. They can cause syncope, embolic phenomena, or mitral valve obstruction, but they do not cause ventricular hypertrophy, arrhythmias, or familial sudden death. Histologically, they consist of stellate or globular myxoma cells in a myxoid stroma, not disorganized myocardium. This diagnosis is incompatible with the findings in this case.

Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Option C): Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterized by ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, not wall thickening. It presents with heart failure symptoms rather than sudden exertional death. Histology typically shows myocyte hypertrophy, interstitial fibrosis, but no myofiber disarray. The echocardiographic finding of a small, slit-like cavitycontradicts this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with easy fatiguability and shortness of breath. Physical examination shows clinical evidence of pulmonary edema, enlargement of the left atrium, and calcification of the mitral valve. A CT scan demonstrates a large mass in the left atrium. A biopsy was taken and send for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a mass in the left atrium, combined with histological findings confirms the diagnosis of myxoma.

  • Cardiac myxomas are typically found in the left atrium (about 75% of cases), usually attached to the interatrial septum near the fossa ovalis.
  • They can obstruct blood flow through the mitral valve, mimicking mitral stenosis, and lead to symptoms such as:
    • Dyspnea
    • Fatigue
    • Orthopnea
    • Pulmonary edema
  • Histologically, myxomas are composed of:
    • Scattered stellate or globular myxoma cells
    • Embedded in a myxoid stroma
    • Often with areas of hemorrhage and chronic inflammation

Rhabdomyoma (Option A): Rhabdomyomas are the most common cardiac tumors in children, especially associated with tuberous sclerosis. They typically occur in the ventricles, not the left atrium. Histology shows "spider cells" - large, vacuolated cells with radial cytoplasmic strands, not the myxoid appearance seen in myxomas.

Adenocarcinoma (Option C): Adenocarcinomas are malignant epithelial tumors that can metastasize to the heart but are not primary cardiac tumors. They typically show glandular structures on histology, which are not a feature of myxomas. Also, adenocarcinomas do not usually present as a solitary left atrial mass.

Carcinoid Tumor (Option D): Carcinoid tumors can affect the heart valves, particularly the right side, due to serotonin-induced fibrosis, leading to tricuspid and pulmonary valve abnormalities. Carcinoid tumors do not form large left atrial masses and typically originate in the gastrointestinal tract with cardiac involvement occurring secondarily.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with severe dyspnea and fatigue. X-ray showed left atrial enlargement. Physician suspects the patient of having mitral stenosis and gets a histopathology examination done, the image of which is shown, it shows??
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 30-year-old male presents with severe dyspnea, fatigue, and left atrial enlargement on X-ray - classic clinical indicators of mitral stenosis.

  • The most common cause of mitral stenosis in young adults, particularly in developing countries, is chronic rheumatic heart disease, which results from prior Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF).
  • Histopathological examination in acute rheumatic carditis reveals Aschoff bodies, which are pathognomonic for rheumatic fever.
  • These are:
    • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by:
      • Lymphocytes
      • Plasma cells
      • Anitschkow cells (activated macrophages with caterpillar-like nuclei)
  • Found in all three layers of the heart (pancarditis), but particularly in the myocardium.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Sarcoidosis can affect the heart and form non-caseating granulomas, but it rarely causes isolated mitral stenosis. Cardiac involvement more commonly results in arrhythmias or conduction defects, not valvular lesions.

Tuberculosis (Option B): Tuberculosis typically causes caseating granulomas and primarily affects the lungs and pericardium (e.g., tuberculous pericarditis), not the mitral valve. It is not a cause of mitral stenosis in young adults.

Fungal granuloma (Option D): Fungal infections can form granulomas, particularly in immunocompromised patients, but are not a typical cause of mitral stenosis or associated with Aschoff bodies. Fungal endocarditis usually leads to vegetations, not fibrotic stenosis.

questions.text: Vegetations of the following endocarditis has the maximum chances of embolization:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the different types of endocarditis, infective endocarditis (IE) — especially the acute form caused by highly virulent organisms like Staphylococcus aureus - is associated with the greatest risk of embolization.

  • This is due to the nature of the vegetations, which are:
    • Large, friable, and bulky
    • Composed of fibrin, platelets, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms
    • Often loosely attached to the valve surface
  • Such vegetation can easily break off and embolize to distant organs like the brain (causing stroke), kidneys, spleen, or even lungs (in right-sided IE).

Explanation of incorrect options:

Rheumatic heart disease (Option A): RHD leads to small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of valve leaflets. These are firmly attached and composed mainly of fibrin and platelet aggregates with minimal risk of embolization. The primary concern in RHD is chronic valve damage, not embolism.

Libman-Sacks endocarditis (Option C): Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Libman-Sacks endocarditis involves sterile vegetations that are small and located on either or both sides of the valve leaflets. Although embolization can occur, the risk is generally lower than that in infective endocarditis.

Subacute bacterial endocarditis (Option D): Caused by low-virulence organisms like Streptococcus viridans, subacute IE has smaller, more organized vegetationsthat are less friable and therefore have a lower risk of embolization compared to acute infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient having large adnexal mass with raised inhibin level. Histopathology shows cord and sheets of tumor cell, often showing nuclear groove as shown in the diagram. Based on the above clinical features, identify the type of tumor.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 55-year-old female presents with a large adnexal mass, raised inhibin levels, and histopathological findings of cords and sheets of tumor cells with nuclear grooves.

  • These findings are classic for granulosa cell tumor, a sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary.
  • Key features supporting the diagnosis:
    • Age group: Typically occurs in postmenopausal women, though it can also be seen in younger females.
    • Hormonal activity: Granulosa cell tumors are often estrogen-producing, leading to endometrial hyperplasia, postmenopausal bleeding, or even precocious puberty in younger girls.
    • Tumor marker: Inhibin (especially inhibin B) is a sensitive tumor marker for granulosa cell tumors.
    • Histology: Shows Call-Exner bodies (small follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic fluid) and "coffee bean" nuclei with longitudinal nuclear grooves.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Choriocarcinoma (Option A):Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant germ cell tumor associated with elevated β-hCG, not inhibin. It shows cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts on histology, and is often associated with hemorrhage and necrosis. It does not show nuclear grooves or cord-like arrangements.

Yolk Sac Tumor (Option C): Also known as endodermal sinus tumor, it is a germ cell tumor that typically elevates AFP (alpha-fetoprotein), not inhibin. Histology shows Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells in a cystic space), not nuclear grooves.

Leydig Cell Tumor (Option D): Leydig cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors that produce androgens, leading to virilization. They are typically identified by Reinke crystals on histology and do not show nuclear grooves or elevated inhibin levels.
